title: Double vision — Myasthenia gravis
chief_complaint: Double vision

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose the patient presenting with double vision, difficulty climbing stairs, and upper limb weakness.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient reports a 1-month history of experiencing double vision (diplopia), difficulty in climbing stairs, and weakness when trying to brush her hair. She notes that these symptoms tend to worsen after physical activity but improve significantly after a few hours of rest.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No significant past medical history.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Non-smoker, drinks wine occasionally. Works as a graphic designer.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Patient denies experiencing any chest pain, palpitations, shortness of breath, or recent infections.

Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: Presence of ptosis (drooping of the right upper eyelid) that worsens with sustained upward gaze.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_Strength: Diminished motor strength observed in the upper extremities, with normal tone and no obvious atrophy.

Electromyography.Findings: Decreased muscle response with repetitive stimulation

Chest_CT.Findings: Normal, no thymoma or other masses detected.

title: Difficulty walking with a 'drunken gait' — Progressive multifocal encephalopathy (PML)
chief_complaint: Difficulty walking with a 'drunken gait'

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and diagnose the patient presenting with gait and limb ataxia, and a significant medical history.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents for a follow-up regarding her Crohn disease, and reports new-onset difficulty walking, described by her peers as 'appearing drunk'. She has a significant history of Crohn disease diagnosed 2 years ago, which has escalated in severity, failing to respond to standard therapies. She has been on natalizumab for the past year.

Secondary_Symptoms: Reduced strength in the right upper limb

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Crohn disease diagnosed 2 years ago, current treatment includes natalizumab for the past year.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Information not provided.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: No additional symptoms provided.

MRI_Brain.Findings: Lesions consistent with Progressive Multifocal Encephalopathy (PML).
MRI_Brain.Comments: T1/T2 images showing multifocal demyelinating lesions without gadolinium enhancement, indicative of PML.

title: Crying, especially intense with abdominal palpation — Hirschsprung disease
chief_complaint: Crying, especially intense with abdominal palpation

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Diagnose the underlying condition based on clinical presentation and examination findings in an 8-month-old boy with feeding difficulties and abdominal distension.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has been very fussy and has shown decreased interest in feeding for the past few days. His mother reports that despite the feeding difficulties, she believes the child has been gaining weight. There were no complications during birth at 39 weeks of gestation.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Crying, especially intense with abdominal palpation

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No significant past medical or surgical history. Delivered vaginally at 39 weeks without complications.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: First child to young parents, no history of similar illness in the family.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: No episodes of fever, vomiting, or diarrhea. The baby has not had any known illnesses since birth.

Abdominal_Examination.Percussion: Tympanitic sound noted in the left lower quadrant
Abdominal_Examination.Palpation: Abdomen is soft but distended, with crying intensifying on palpation especially in the left lower quadrant

Abdominal_X-ray.Findings: Dilated bowel segments with absence of gas in the rectum, suggesting a possible obstruction

Barium_Enema.Findings: A transition zone in the distal colon, compatible with Hirschsprung disease

title: Fatigue, abdominal pain — Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma
chief_complaint: Fatigue, abdominal pain

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and diagnose the patient presenting with fatigue, abdominal pain, night sweats, weight loss, and enlarged supraclavicular lymph node.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient reports experiencing fatigue, worsening abdominal pain for the past 4 weeks, excessive night sweats, and a noticeable weight loss of approximately 5.4 kg (12 lb). Additionally, the patient noticed neck swelling developing over the last 4 days.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: The patient does not report any significant past medical history. No previous major illnesses or surgeries.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: The patient has a history of smoking, 1 pack per day for the past 30 years. Drinks alcohol socially. Works in a construction company.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Patient also reports feeling an unusual fullness in the belly area and has difficulty wearing his usual clothing due to this. Denies fever, cough, or recent travel.

Neck_Examination.Inspection_and_Palpation: Nontender, enlarged, and fixed supraclavicular lymph node observed.

Abdominal_Examination.Percussion: Dullness noted over the left lower quadrant.
Abdominal_Examination.Palpation: Splenomegaly detected, without rebound tenderness.

CT_Scan_Thorax_and_Abdomen.Findings: Massively enlarged axillary, mediastinal, and cervical lymph nodes.

Cervical_Lymph_Node.Findings: Lymphocytes with a high proliferative index that stain positive for CD20.

title: Fatigue, flank pain, and fever — Acute interstitial nephritis
chief_complaint: Fatigue, flank pain, and fever

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose the patient presenting with fatigue, flank pain, and fever after recent antibiotic treatment for acute sinusitis.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with complaints of fatigue, flank pain, and a persistent fever. She reports that these symptoms have continued despite the resolution of her sinusitis symptoms. She was initially treated with amoxicillin for acute sinusitis for 12 days, during which she developed a rash. The antibiotic was then changed to cephalexin for an additional week, and the rash resolved. She has a medical history of essential hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and gastric reflux and has been on a stable regimen of lisinopril, simvastatin, and omeprazole.

Secondary_Symptoms: History of rash during antibiotic treatment
Persistent symptoms despite resolution of initial sinusitis

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Essential hypertension, hyperlipidemia, gastric reflux
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Non-smoker, drinks alcohol socially, retired school teacher.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies nausea, vomiting, dysuria, or recent changes in urine color. Reports a resolved skin rash.

General_Examination.Abdomen: Mild flank tenderness, no rebound or guarding

Urinalysis.Cytospin_Stained_With_Hansel’s_Solution: 3% binucleated cells with eosinophilic, granular cytoplasm

title: Knee pain, specifically over the medial aspect of the tibia just inferior to the patella — Pes anserine bursitis
chief_complaint: Knee pain, specifically over the medial aspect of the tibia just inferior to the patella

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose the patient presenting with knee pain following recent increased physical activity.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with knee pain that started yesterday and has been steadily worsening. She cites recent participation in volleyball involving repetitive pivoting and twisting movements as a possible cause. She was advised at her last physical exam that weight loss could be beneficial for her health.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Knee pain, specifically over the medial aspect of the tibia just inferior to the patella

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), currently managed with oral contraceptive pills.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Has recently joined a volleyball team.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies any fever, recent injuries, swelling or discoloration of the knee, or previous similar complaints.

Lower_Extremity_Examination.Inspection: No visible abnormalities, erythema, or swelling.
Lower_Extremity_Examination.Palpation: Tenderness over the medial aspect of the tibia just inferior to the patella.
Lower_Extremity_Examination.Range_of_Motion: Full range of motion without significant pain or limitation.

X-Ray_Knee.Findings: No fracture, dislocation, or appreciable joint effusion.

MRI_Knee.Optional: Can be considered if clinical suspicion persists despite negative initial workup, not mandatory for diagnosis in this simulated case.

title: Episode of loss of consciousness — Situational syncope
chief_complaint: Episode of loss of consciousness

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose the patient presenting with an episode of loss of consciousness.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient was brought to the emergency department after an episode of loss of consciousness that occurred 1 hour ago, immediately after micturating. His wife found him unconscious on the bathroom floor. He regained consciousness after about 30 seconds without any confusion or amnesia for the event. No history of urinary incontinence during the event.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No significant past medical or surgical history. Not on any regular medications.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Non-smoker. Drinks alcohol socially. Works as a high school teacher. No recent travel or sick contacts.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies chest pain, palpitations, fevers, headaches, seizures, recent illnesses, or any other neurological symptoms.

Cardiopulmonary_Examination.Heart: Normal rate, regular rhythm, no murmurs.
Cardiopulmonary_Examination.Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.

Neurologic_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert and oriented to person, place, time, and situation.
Neurologic_Examination.Motor: Normal strength and tone in all extremities.

title: Continuous heart murmur — Congenital Rubella Infection
chief_complaint: Continuous heart murmur

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose the newborn with specific findings on physical examination and history provided.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient is a 3000-g (6.6-lb) female newborn delivered at term to a 23-year-old primigravida mother. The mother reports having had no prenatal care, and immunization records for the newborn are not available.

Secondary_Symptoms: Bluish macules on the skin that do not blanch with pressure
Cloudy lenses in both eyes noticed upon examination
Failure to pass auditory screening tests

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Newborn, no past medical history available.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Mother is a primigravida, no prenatal care received.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: No additional symptoms noted by the mother.

Skin_Examination.Macules: Several bluish macules that do not blanch upon application of pressure

title: Presence of a left breast mass — Phyllodes tumor
chief_complaint: Presence of a left breast mass

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and diagnose the patient presenting with a breast mass.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient noticed a mass in her left breast 4 weeks ago, which has rapidly increased in size. She denies any recent trauma or infections. No history of similar complaints in the past.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Presence of a left breast mass
Secondary_Symptoms: Rapid increase in size of the mass
No pain associated with the mass

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No significant past medical or surgical history. No family history of breast cancer.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Non-smoker, moderate alcohol use. Elementary school teacher.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies fever, weight loss, night sweats, or changes in appetite.

Breast_Examination.Inspection: No skin changes, nipple retraction, or discharge.
Breast_Examination.Palpation: A 6-cm, nontender, multinodular mass palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. No palpable axillary or cervical lymphadenopathy.

Mammography.Findings: Smooth polylobulated mass in the left breast.

Biopsy.Microscopic_Description: Image shows leaf-like structures with stromal cellular overgrowth.

title: Uterine tenderness — Endometritis
chief_complaint: Uterine tenderness

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and manage a patient presenting with postpartum fever and abdominal tenderness.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient is in the postpartum period after delivering an 11 pound boy vaginally at 40 weeks gestation. She experienced a prolonged course during labor. She reports increased frequency of urination and uterine tenderness. She also mentions a decrease in bowel sounds.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Uncomplicated pregnancy leading up to a vaginal delivery. No significant past medical or surgical history.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Lives with her partner.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Complains of minor difficulty in breathing but denies any urinary pain, headache, vomiting, or diarrhea.

Abdominal_Examination.Palpation: Tender uterus

Pulmonary_Examination.Findings: Minor bibasilar crackles, no signs of respiratory distress

title: Rectal bleeding daily with bowel movements — Hemorrhoids
chief_complaint: Rectal bleeding daily with bowel movements

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose the patient presenting with rectal bleeding and a palpable rectal mass.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient reports a 2-week history of rectal bleeding occurring daily with bowel movements. She denies any pain with defecation and does not present with any other complaints.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Rectal bleeding daily with bowel movements

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: The patient's past medical history is unremarkable except for 5 normal vaginal deliveries.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Information not specified.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: The patient denies any changes in bowel habits, abdominal pain, weight loss, or other systemic symptoms.

Rectovaginal_Examination.Findings: A palpable, non-tender, prolapsed mass that can be easily pushed back into the anal sphincter by the examiner's finger.

title: Recurrent episodes of facial grimacing and staring — Complex partial seizure
chief_complaint: Recurrent episodes of facial grimacing and staring

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and diagnose the patient presenting with episodes of unresponsiveness accompanied by facial grimacing.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has been experiencing recurrent episodes lasting 3–4 minutes each of facial grimacing and staring over the past month. During these episodes, he is nonresponsive and does not recall them afterward. He reports a muddy taste in his mouth before the onset of these episodes. His brother witnessed him waking up, staring, and making hand gestures during one episode. The patient felt lethargic and confused afterwards.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Recurrent episodes of facial grimacing and staring

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No significant previous medical history. No prior seizures or neurological evaluations.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Enrolled in second grade. Lives with parents and one sibling. No reported use of medications or exposure to toxins.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies fever, headache, visual or auditory disturbances, weakness, or other systemic symptoms.

Neurological_Examination.General: Alert and oriented for age. No acute distress noted.
Neurological_Examination.Motor: Normal tone, strength, and bulk in all four extremities.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory: Intact to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception.
Neurological_Examination.Coordination: No dysmetria on finger-nose-finger or heel-knee-shin tests.

Electroencephalogram.Findings: Interictal spikes and sharp waves localized to the temporal lobes, more prominent on the right side.

MRI_Brain.Findings: No evidence of mass lesions, infarctions, or structural abnormalities.

title: Severe right groin pain — Posterior hip dislocation
chief_complaint: Severe right groin pain

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Conduct a thorough assessment of a patient presenting with right groin pain and abnormal leg positioning following a rear-end collision, and diagnose appropriately.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient was involved in a rear-end collision where she was the restrained driver of the back car. She reports immediate onset of pain in both knees and severe pain over the right groin area following the accident.

Secondary_Symptoms: Right leg is slightly shortened, flexed, adducted, and internally rotated

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No significant past medical history.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Works as an elementary school teacher. Non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Alert and active. No head injury, abdominal pain, or chest pain reported.

Musculoskeletal_Examination.Inspection: The right leg is slightly shortened, flexed, adducted, and internally rotated. No visible wounds.

Range_of_Motion.Right_Leg: Limited due to pain and abnormal positioning

Pelvic_X-ray.Findings: No fractures identified in the pelvic ring or femoral neck, but alignment suggests posterior dislocation of the right hip.

title: Bilious vomiting — Hirschsprung’s disease
chief_complaint: Bilious vomiting

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose the infant brought in by a concerned mother due to bilious vomiting and inability to pass meconium, with observed abdominal distension.

Patient_Actor.History: The infant was born via a home birth without complications. The mother reports that the infant has had bilious vomiting and has not been able to pass meconium since birth. She also notes that the infant's abdomen appears distended.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Newborn, no prior medical history. Birth was uneventful.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: The infant is the first child of the family. No known family history of genetic or congenital diseases.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: The infant shows signs of distress, possibly due to abdominal discomfort.

Abdominal_Examination.Palpation: The abdomen is firm and distended, with palpable bowel loops; the infant shows signs of discomfort during palpation.

Abdominal_X-ray.Findings: Dilated loops of bowel with no gas in the rectum, suggestive of a distal obstruction.

Rectal_Biopsy.Histopathology: Absence of ganglion cells in the submucosa and myenteric plexus, consistent with Hirschsprung’s disease.

title: Progressive swelling and pain in the right ring finger — Rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon at its point of insertion
chief_complaint: Progressive swelling and pain in the right ring finger
correct_diagnosis: Rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon at its point of insertion

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and diagnose the patient presenting with progressive swelling and pain in the right ring finger.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient reports that the pain and swelling in his right ring finger began 2 days ago while playing football. He recalls his finger got caught in the jersey of another player, who then pulled away forcefully.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Progressive swelling and pain in the right ring finger
Secondary_Symptoms: Inability to flex the right ring finger at the distal interphalangeal joint when making a fist
Pain at the distal interphalangeal joint
Extended right ring finger in resting position

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No significant medical history.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Student and active in sports, particularly football. Non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies fever, numbness, or tingling in the affected finger.

Hand_Examination.Inspection: Right ring finger is extended, with visible swelling at the distal interphalangeal joint.
Hand_Examination.Palpation: Tenderness localized at the distal interphalangeal joint of the right ring finger.
Hand_Examination.Range_of_Motion: Patient unable to flex the right ring finger at the distal interphalangeal joint while attempting to make a fist. No joint laxity.
Hand_Examination.Neurovascular_Assessment: Normal capillary refill, no sensory deficits.

X-ray_of_the_Right_Hand.Findings: No bone fractures or dislocations visible. Soft tissue swelling noted around the distal interphalangeal joint of the right ring finger.

MRI_of_the_Right_Hand.Preliminary_Findings: Expected to show details regarding the integrity of tendons.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon at its point of insertion

title: Progressively increasing swelling on the nape of neck for 2 months — Epidermoid cyst
chief_complaint: Progressively increasing swelling on the nape of neck for 2 months

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and diagnose the patient presenting with a neck swelling.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient reports a progressively increasing swelling on the nape of his neck for 2 months. He denies having a fever, pain, or any discharge from the swelling. He mentions a history of colon cancer for which he underwent colectomy at the age of 43. He also has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and osteoarthritis of the left knee. He takes insulin glargine, metformin, enalapril, and naproxen.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Progressively increasing swelling on the nape of neck for 2 months
Secondary_Symptoms: No pain associated with the swelling

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Colon cancer (colectomy performed), type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, osteoarthritis of the left knee.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Works as a traffic warden, frequently plays golf.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Overall healthy appearance, no other complaints or symptoms noted.

Neck_Examination.Inspection_and_Palpation: A 2.5-cm (1-in) firm, mobile, painless nodule on the nape of the neck. The skin over the nodule cannot be pinched.

Lung_Examination.Auscultation: Clear lungs bilaterally, no rales, rhonchi, or wheezes.

Ultrasound_of_the_Neck.Findings: Well-circumscribed lesion in the subcutaneous tissue suggestive of a cystic nature.

title: Watery diarrhea — C. difficile colitis
chief_complaint: Watery diarrhea

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate the patient for the cause of acute diarrhea and manage appropriately.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has been treated for community-acquired pneumonia with levofloxacin on the medical floor. She reports developing watery diarrhea with at least 9 episodes within the last two days, accompanied by lower abdominal discomfort and cramping.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Currently being treated for community-acquired pneumonia. No other significant past medical history.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Non-smoker, does not consume alcohol. No recent travel or dietary changes reported.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: No fever, no recent antibiotics usage apart from levofloxacin for pneumonia, no vomiting, no blood in stool.

Abdominal_Examination.Palpation: Diffuse mild tenderness in the lower abdomen, no guarding or rebound tenderness.

title: Painful ulcerative lesion on the right leg — Pyoderma gangrenosum
chief_complaint: Painful ulcerative lesion on the right leg

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and diagnose the patient presenting with a painful, ulcerative skin lesion on her leg.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient reports a skin lesion on her right leg that has been present for 1 month. The lesion began as a small red spot and has increased in size. She recalls an ant bite at the site before the lesion developed. She has a history of anterior uveitis treated with corticosteroids 8 months ago, as well as Crohn's disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypertension.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Painful ulcerative lesion on the right leg
Secondary_Symptoms: Lesion has a central necrotic base and purplish irregular borders
History of ant bite at the site of the lesion
Pitting pedal edema of the lower extremities
Dilated tortuous veins in both lower legs

Past_Medical_History: Treated for anterior uveitis 8 months ago
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Recently returned from a visit to Wisconsin 2 months ago.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: No additional systemic symptoms mentioned.

Skin_Examination.Inspection: A 4-cm tender ulcerative lesion on the anterior right leg with a central necrotic base and purplish irregular borders. Pitting pedal edema is noted along with dilated tortuous veins in both lower legs.
Skin_Examination.Palpation: Tenderness over the lesion. Femoral and pedal pulses palpable bilaterally.

Histopathology.Findings: Neutrophilic infiltration without infection, consistent with pyoderma gangrenosum.

title: Vaginal bleeding — Uterine rupture
chief_complaint: Vaginal bleeding

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and manage a pregnant patient presenting with vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain.

Patient_Actor.Demographics: 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 38 weeks' gestation
Patient_Actor.History: The patient reports experiencing vaginal bleeding for the past hour accompanied by severe abdominal pain. She mentions that she felt contractions before the onset of the bleeding, but the contractions ceased once the bleeding began. Her first childbirth was a cesarean section due to nonreassuring fetal heart rate.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: One previous childbirth via cesarean section. No other significant past medical history.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Non-smoker, occasional alcohol consumption. Works as an elementary school teacher.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Reports feeling the baby move before the onset of symptoms but is unsure about movement since the symptoms started. Denies any recent trauma to the abdomen or any urinary symptoms.

Abdominal_Examination.Palpation: Diffuse abdominal tenderness without rebound or guarding

Obstetric_Examination.Uterine_Examination: No contractions felt at the time of examination

Ultrasound_Abdomen_and_Pelvis.Findings: Suggestive of a disruption in the uterine wall continuity adjacent to the scar from the previous cesarean section, with associated hemoperitoneum.

title: Sharp lower back pain radiating to the leg and foot — Disc herniation
chief_complaint: Sharp lower back pain radiating to the leg and foot

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and diagnose the patient presenting with sudden-onset lower back pain radiating down the leg.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient reports exercising in the gym several hours ago when she suddenly felt a sharp pain in her lower back. She describes the pain as radiating down the side of her leg and into her foot.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Sharp lower back pain radiating to the leg and foot
Secondary_Symptoms: The onset of pain while exercising

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No significant past medical history. No prior episodes of similar pain.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Non-smoker, rarely drinks alcohol. Regular gym-goer.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies fever, weight loss, changes in bowel or bladder function.

Musculoskeletal_Examination.Inspection: Normal spine curvature, no visible swelling.
Musculoskeletal_Examination.Palpation: Tenderness localized to the lower lumbar spine.
Musculoskeletal_Examination.Special_Test: Positive straight leg raise test with pain radiating down the leg.

Neurological_Examination.Sensation: Intact to light touch and pin-prick throughout the leg and foot.

MRI_Lumbar_Spine.Findings: Evidence of L5-S1 disc herniation impinging on the adjacent nerve root.

title: Decreased vision and black spots in the right eye — Cytomegalovirus retinitis
chief_complaint: Decreased vision and black spots in the right eye

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and diagnose a 34-year-old male patient presenting with decreased vision and seeing black spots in his right eye, having a medical history of AIDS.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Decreased vision and black spots in the right eye

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: AIDS, fungal esophagitis treated with fluconazole, Kaposi's sarcoma
Patient_Actor.Social_History: No additional information provided
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: No additional symptoms mentioned

General_Examination.Skin_Examination: Multiple violaceous plaques over the trunk and extremities

Eye_Examination.Fundoscopy: Granular yellow-white opacities around the retinal vessels and multiple areas of dot-blot hemorrhages

title: Pain and swelling in the right knee — Reactive Arthritis
chief_complaint: Pain and swelling in the right knee

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and diagnose the patient presenting with increasing pain and swelling of his right knee, episodes of pain with urination, and a history of a painful, swollen left ankle joint that resolved without treatment.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has been experiencing increasing pain and swelling in his right knee for the past 12 days. He reports pain with urination for the past 3 weeks and had a swollen, painful left ankle joint that resolved on its own about a week ago. He mentions being sexually active with 2 female partners and using condoms inconsistently. He also reveals that his mother has rheumatoid arthritis. The patient appears anxious.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Pain and swelling in the right knee
Secondary_Symptoms: History of painful, swollen left ankle joint
Tenderness at the left Achilles tendon insertion site

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No significant past medical history reported.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Sexually active with multiple partners, inconsistent condom use.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Experiences anxiety; denies recent flu-like symptoms, denies any known sexually transmitted infections.

Musculoskeletal_Examination.Right_Knee: Tender, erythematous, swollen, limited range of motion due to pain
Musculoskeletal_Examination.Left_Ankle: No visible swelling or erythema but history of previous symptoms

title: Skin lesion on the chest — Malignant melanoma
chief_complaint: Skin lesion on the chest

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose the patient presenting with a chest skin lesion.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient reports noticing a skin lesion on his chest 2 months ago, which he believes has increased in size. He denies any associated pain or itching with the lesion. He has a medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia, and glaucoma.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia, glaucoma
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Smokes 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years, drinks two to three beers on weekends
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies recent weight loss, fever, fatigue, or changes in appetite.

Skin_Examination.Inspection: A single, partly elevated lesion located on the chest. The lesion exhibits asymmetry, border irregularity, and varied color with diameter larger than 6mm.
Skin_Examination.Palpation: The lesion is firm on palpation with a partly elevated nature, and it does not change form on pinching.

Skin_Biopsy.Histopathology_Findings: Atypical melanocytes that infiltrate the epidermis and dermis, confirming the diagnosis of malignant melanoma.

title: Chronic diarrhea — Irritable Bowel Syndrome
chief_complaint: Chronic diarrhea

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and diagnose the patient presenting with chronic diarrhea and lower abdominal discomfort.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient reports experiencing chronic diarrhea on most days for the past four months. She mentions lower abdominal discomfort and cramping, which is relieved by diarrhea. The patient notes the bowel movements are urgent, occasionally accompanied by mucus discharge, and often followed by a feeling of incomplete evacuation. She went camping several months ago and recalls another member of the camping party falling ill recently.

Secondary_Symptoms: Sensation of urgency before bowel movement
Feeling of incomplete evacuation post bowel movement

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No notable past medical history provided.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: No pertinent social history related to symptoms.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies any recent weight change, fever, nausea, or vomiting.

Abdominal_Examination.Palpation: Mild diffuse abdominal discomfort but no rebound tenderness or guarding.

title: Shortness of breath — Meigs syndrome
chief_complaint: Shortness of breath

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and diagnose the patient presenting with shortness of breath, increased abdominal girth, and a large ovarian mass.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient reports experiencing shortness of breath and noticeable increase in abdominal size over the past month. She denies any significant medical history, previous surgeries, or use of medications.

Secondary_Symptoms: No significant weight loss or gain

Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Reports a new onset cough along with skin and mucosal changes but denies fever, shortness of breath, joint pains, gastrointestinal symptoms, or recent illnesses.

Skin_Examination.General: Coalescing erythematous macules, bullae, desquamation noted.
Skin_Examination.Distribution: Localized to the upper half of the back.
Skin_Examination.Mucous_Membranes: Ulcers and erythema present in oropharynx.

Cardiopulmonary_Exam.Cardiac: Normal rate and rhythm, no murmurs or gallops.
Cardiopulmonary_Exam.Pulmonary: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Abdominal_Exam: Soft, non-tender, no hepatosplenomegaly, normoactive bowel sounds throughout.

Skin_Biopsy.Findings: Epidermal necrosis and detachment, consistent with severe drug reaction.

title: Delayed menarche — Aromatase deficiency
chief_complaint: Delayed menarche

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and diagnose the adolescent patient presenting with delayed menarche, unusual physical features, and a history suggestive of bone fragility.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has not experienced menarche. She was noted to have partial labial fusion and clitoromegaly at birth. The patient's mother reports that during pregnancy she had abnormal hair growth on her chin. The patient has a history of severe acne and has sustained fractures following minor trauma. She is currently on oral isotretinoin and an oral contraceptive.

Secondary_Symptoms: History of fractures following minor trauma
Partial labial fusion and clitoromegaly noted at birth

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Currently taking oral isotretinoin for acne and an oral contraceptive.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: The patient is a high school student without significant tobacco, alcohol, or drug use.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies any recent illnesses, appetite change, or weight change.

Skin_Examination.Findings: Numerous inflamed pustules on the face and upper back.

Breast_Examination.Findings: Breast development is at Tanner stage I.

Pelvic_Ultrasound.Findings: Ovaries with multiple cysts and a normal uterus.

title: Significant rapid breathing — Atrial Septal Defect
chief_complaint: Significant rapid breathing

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose the child presenting with rapid breathing, abnormal physical findings including liver enlargement, and pitting edema.

Patient_Actor.History: The parents report that the child appears unwell and has been breathing rapidly. They also noticed some swelling in the child's legs but no fever, cough, or previous similar episodes. The child's appetite has diminished over the past few days. No recent illnesses or hospitalizations. The child is fully immunized.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No significant past medical history. Birth history unremarkable.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Lives with both parents and one older sibling. No known exposure to sick contacts or recent travel.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: On review, there's no history of cough, fever, vomiting, or diarrhea.

Cardiovascular_Examination.Auscultation: Mild rales noted, fixed split S2 on inspiration. No murmurs.

Respiratory_Examination.Auscultation: Increased respiratory effort, no wheezes or stridor.

Abdominal_Examination.Palpation: Liver palpable 1.5 times the normal size for age, no splenomegaly.

Extremities.Inspection_and_Palpation: Mild pitting edema in both legs.

Chest_X-Ray.Findings: Enlarged cardiac silhouette, no pulmonary edema.

Echocardiogram.Findings: Presence of an atrial septal defect with left to right shunt.

title: Yellow discoloration of the skin — Pancreatic adenocarcinoma
chief_complaint: Yellow discoloration of the skin

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess the patient and determine the cause of jaundice, pruritus, weight loss, pale stool, and dark urine.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has experienced gradual yellow discoloration of the skin and generalized pruritus over the past 2 weeks. He also reports a decreased appetite and a weight loss of 6.3 kg (14 lb). The patient’s stool has been pale, and his urine is very dark. Three years ago, he had an episode of acute upper abdominal pain, which was managed with IV fluids, NSAIDs, and dietary modification. The patient has abstained from alcohol for these three years, after having consumed 1–2 beers daily for 40 years. He has a 50-year history of smoking a pack of cigarettes daily.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Episode of acute upper abdominal pain treated three years ago. History of long-term alcohol consumption and smoking.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Stopped alcohol consumption three years ago; 50-year history of smoking a pack of cigarettes daily.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: No additional symptoms were reported.

Abdominal_Examination.Inspection: Jaundice noted in the conjunctivae and skin.
Abdominal_Examination.Palpation: No tenderness, but a soft, cystic mass palpated in the right upper quadrant.

Abdominal_Ultrasonography.Findings: Anechoic cystic mass in the subhepatic region. Dilation of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.

title: Episodes of dizziness and spinning sensation — Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV)
chief_complaint: Episodes of dizziness and spinning sensation

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and manage a patient presenting with episodes of dizziness and vertigo.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with sudden episodes of dizziness that are position dependent. She describes experiencing a false sensation of motion and occasional spinning, indicative of vertigo. She denies any recent illnesses, injuries, or significant changes in health status, apart from age-related hearing loss (presbycusis).

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Episodes of dizziness and spinning sensation

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No significant past medical or surgical history. No history of Meniere's disease, vestibular neuritis, or labyrinthitis.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Retired school teacher. Lives alone. Non-smoker, occasional wine. Enjoys light gardening.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies headache, tinnitus, hearing loss, nausea, vomiting, or recent respiratory infections.

Neurological_Examination.Gait: Steady, no signs of imbalance when not experiencing vertigo

Positional_Testing.Dix-Hallpike_Manoeuvre: Positive for right-sided horizontal nystagmus when moving from sitting to supine position, suggestive of BPPV

Audiometry.Findings: Bilateral high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss, consistent with presbycusis. No sudden drops in hearing indicative of Meniere’s disease or labyrinthitis.

Vestibular_Function_Tests.Videonystagmography: Normal vestibular response with the exception of response elicited during Dix-Hallpike maneuver, consistent with BPPV.

MRI_Brain.Findings: No evidence of central lesions or infarcts that would suggest central causes of vertigo.

title: Belief in telepathic communication with animals — Schizotypal personality disorder
chief_complaint: Belief in telepathic communication with animals

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and diagnose the patient presenting with unusual behavior and beliefs regarding telepathic communication with animals.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a chief complaint of 'failing health.' He reports an inability to communicate telepathically with animals, which he believes he could previously do, affected by the current weather conditions. He has started taking assorted Peruvian herbs without any improvement. He denies taking any medications. The symptoms have been ongoing for the past eight months.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Belief in telepathic communication with animals

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Patient is not on any medication and has no significant past medical history.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Lives alone, works at a health food store. Dresses in all burlap clothing and attempts telepathic communication during history taking.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies any other physical complaints or symptoms.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Healthy appearing young man, fully oriented, dressed in burlap clothes.

Mental_Status_Exam.Behavior: Attempts to communicate telepathically during interview
Mental_Status_Exam.Mood_and_Affect: Mood is euthymic, affect is congruent.
Mental_Status_Exam.Thought_Content: Presence of odd beliefs and magical thinking
Mental_Status_Exam.Insight_and_Judgment: Insight is poor, judgment is questionable due to self-treatment with herbs for his condition.

title: Non-healing, crusty, red lesions on the penile shaft and left middle finger — Bowen's Disease
chief_complaint: Non-healing, crusty, red lesions on the penile shaft and left middle finger

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and diagnose the dermatological condition presented by the patient, focusing on lesions with potential oncologic implications.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has recently immigrated to the US from Africa and seeks evaluation for a non-healing, red, crusty lesion on the shaft of his penis and a similar lesion on his left middle finger. Previous treatments in his home country for syphilis and eczema have been unsuccessful. The patient is a smoker, with a history of two packs per day for the last 30 years.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Non-healing, crusty, red lesions on the penile shaft and left middle finger
Secondary_Symptoms: History of unsuccessful treatment for syphilis and eczema

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No known malignancies or hereditary diseases in the family. Previous treatments for syphilis and eczema.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Lives with his 4th wife, smokes 2 packs of cigarettes per day for the last 30 years, has recently immigrated from Africa.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies any systemic symptoms such as fever, weight loss, night sweats, or malaise. No other similar lesions elsewhere on the body.

Dermatological_Examination.Inspection: An erythematous plaque with areas of crusting, oozing, and irregular borders observed on the dorsal surface of the penile shaft and on the left middle finger.
Dermatological_Examination.Palpation: Lesions are firm to touch, non-tender, with no warmth.
Dermatological_Examination.Regional_Lymph_Nodes: No palpable cervical, axillary, or inguinal lymphadenopathy.

Biopsy.Findings: Cells with nuclear hyperchromasia, multinucleation, and increased mitotic figures within the follicle-bearing epithelium.

title: Behavioral issues at school — Oppositional Defiant Disorder
chief_complaint: Behavioral issues at school

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose the patient presenting with behavior issues at school and at home.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has been increasingly disruptive in class according to his teacher. He often refuses to participate in directed activities with responses such as 'You're not the boss of me' or 'You can't make me.' He is reluctant to participate in gym class, though he engages actively in similar physical activities during recess. His social interactions with peers are positive, and he is described as well-liked by his classmates. The patient's mother describes him as occasionally difficult but notes that he is helpful at home and plays well with his younger sister.

Secondary_Symptoms: Reluctance to participate in certain school activities
Helpful and cooperative behavior at home

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No significant past medical or psychiatric history.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Lives with mother, father, and a younger sister. Performs well academically when he chooses to engage. No known substance use in the family.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies any symptoms of depression or anxiety. No history of bullying or feeling unsafe at school or home.

General_Examination.Appearance: Well-nourished, well-groomed male in no acute distress.
General_Examination.Psychiatric_Evaluation: Appropriate mood and affect. No evidence of thought disorders. Exhibits some oppositional behaviors during interview.

Parent_and_Teacher_Behavioral_Checklists.Scores: Indicate patterns consistent with oppositional behaviors without conduct problems.

Psychological_Evaluation.Findings: No evidence of an anxiety disorder, depression, or ADHD.

title: Fatigue — Pancreatic adenocarcinoma
chief_complaint: Fatigue

chief_complaint: Severe abdominal pain and cramping

title: Occasional shooting pain in the ear with eating — Glossopharyngeal Neuralgia
chief_complaint: Occasional shooting pain in the ear with eating

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and diagnose the patient presenting with occasional shooting ear pain and difficulty wearing earrings post tympanoplasty.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient has a history of polycystic ovarian syndrome, depression, and chronic bilateral ear infections. She underwent right ear tympanoplasty 12 weeks ago. Although audiology report from one week ago showed improved hearing by 20 decibels, she reports occasional shooting pain when eating and discomfort when wearing earrings. She describes her job as stressful and mentions poor sleep quality.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Occasional shooting pain in the ear with eating

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: History of polycystic ovarian syndrome, depression, and chronic bilateral ear infections. Underwent right ear tympanoplasty 12 weeks prior.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Works as a cashier at a local department store.

Review_of_Systems.ENT: Reports shooting pain and discomfort in the right ear. Denies neck pain or facial tenderness.

ENT_Examination.Mandibular_Area: No jaw clicking heard. No tenderness with palpation.
ENT_Examination.Postauricular_Area: Right postauricular tapping causes tenderness in right tonsillar area.
ENT_Examination.Oral_Exam: Even and symmetric molar teeth bilaterally. Uvula is midline. Gag reflex intact.

Audiology_Report_One_Week_Ago.Findings: Improved hearing by 20 decibels post tympanoplasty.

Additional_Tests.Suggestion: MRI of the brainstem and cerebellopontine angle with and without contrast could be considered to rule out underlying causes if clinical suspicion persists.

title: Recurrent episodes of stridor and wheezing — Double aortic arch
chief_complaint: Recurrent episodes of stridor and wheezing

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Recurrent episodes of stridor and wheezing

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No significant past medical or surgical history. Born full term with no complications during birth.

Respiratory_Examination.Palpation: No crepitus or significant findings on palpation

Chest_X-ray.Findings: Evidence of tracheal compression and a vascular ring suggestive of a double aortic arch

Echocardiogram.Findings: Confirmatory findings of a double aortic arch

title: Persistent sadness — Schizoaffective disorder
chief_complaint: Persistent sadness

She describes a feeling of emptiness and experiences auditory hallucinations, specifically voices telling her she is worthless. These hallucinations began 7 months ago, initially with the voices mocking her. The patient denies using alcohol or illicit substances.

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No significant past medical history.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Denies alcohol or illicit drug use. No other relevant social history provided.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: She denies any other systemic symptoms.

Mental_Status_Examination.Appearance: Dressed appropriately but displays minimal self-care.
Mental_Status_Examination.Behavior: No overt agitation, but appears withdrawn.
Mental_Status_Examination.Speech: Slow, monotonous, with occasional stopping mid-sentence without completion.
Mental_Status_Examination.Thought_Process: Linear but impaired due to auditory hallucinations.
Mental_Status_Examination.Thought_Content: Auditory hallucinations with derogatory content, feelings of worthlessness.
Mental_Status_Examination.Perception: Occasionally directs attention towards ceiling as if listening to someone.
Mental_Status_Examination.Cognition: No formal testing, but patient appears oriented.
Mental_Status_Examination.Insight/Judgment: Not fully assessed but likely impaired due to symptoms.

title: Intense itching on the right thigh — Bed bug bite

Patient_Actor.History: The baby was born via cesarean delivery. The mother had gestational diabetes but was otherwise healthy with no other pregnancy-related diseases.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: The mother had gestational diabetes. No other significant family or prenatal history.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Not applicable
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: The cyanosis improves with oxygen administration. No feeding difficulties were noted prior to onset of symptoms.

Vital_Signs.Oxygen_Saturation: 88% on room air, improving with oxygen

Respiratory_Examination.Inspection: Cyanosis noted, especially around the lips. Subcostal and intercostal retractions present.

title: Multiple, flaccid blisters on the volar surface of the forearm — Pemphigus vulgaris

She has been hiking in the woods recently but denies contact with poison ivy. She has a history of hypertension and osteoarthritis, recently started taking captopril, and discontinued meloxicam 2 weeks ago. Family history includes pernicious anemia and Graves' disease.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Multiple, flaccid blisters on the volar surface of the forearm
Secondary_Symptoms: Ulcers on the buccal, gingival, and vulvar mucosa
Pain in the left cheek when eating

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Hypertension, osteoarthritis.
Patient_Actor.Drug_History: Recently started captopril, stopped taking meloxicam 2 weeks ago.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Has started hiking in the woods on weekends. No relevant travel history.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: No recent illnesses, denies fever, respiratory symptoms, or gastrointestinal symptoms.

Skin_Examination.Inspection: Multiple, flaccid blisters on the volar surface of the forearm, with 10% total body surface area involvement.
Skin_Examination.Palpation: Skin separation (Nikolsky sign positive) when lightly stroked.
Skin_Examination.Mucosal_Examination: Ulcers present on the buccal, gingival, and vulvar mucosa.

Direct_Immunofluorescence.Findings: Intercellular IgG and C3 deposition within the epidermis.

title: Right leg weakness and unsteady gait — Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
chief_complaint: Right leg weakness and unsteady gait

Over the past 6 months, the patient has been increasingly forgetful, losing his way on familiar routes and facing difficulties operating simple kitchen appliances. He has also been paranoid, agitated, and restless recently.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Right leg weakness and unsteady gait

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Known history of HIV, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Noncompliance with medications for over 2 years.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Information not provided
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: The patient is somnolent and slightly confused, oriented to person but not to place or time. Mild lymphadenopathy is noted.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Somnolent, slightly confused, oriented to person but not place or time.
Neurological_Examination.Motor: Right lower extremity weakness with normal tone, no other focal deficits.

MRI_Brain.Findings: Disseminated, nonenhancing white matter lesions with no mass effect.

title: Generalized fatigue — Acute myelogenous leukemia
chief_complaint: Generalized fatigue

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose the patient presenting with generalized fatigue, pallor, and abnormal blood findings.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient complains of a 2-month history of generalized fatigue. He mentions no specific triggers but notes that the fatigue has been progressively worsening. He denies any recent infections, significant weight loss, or night sweats.

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No significant past medical history. No known blood disorders or cancer history in the family.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Retired teacher, lives with his wife. Non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies fever, significant weight loss, night sweats, or recent infections. Mentions occasional mild shortness of breath during exertion.

General_Examination.Skin_Examination: Multiple pinpoint, red, nonblanching spots (petechiae) noted on the extremities.

Abdominal_Examination.Palpation: Significant splenomegaly.

Peripheral_Blood_Smear.Findings: Presence of immature cells with large, prominent nucleoli and pink, elongated, needle-shaped cytoplasmic inclusions.

title: Bizarre and agitated behavior — Schizophreniform Disorder
chief_complaint: Bizarre and agitated behavior

His wife adds that he has been increasingly withdrawn and intermittently depressed over the last 3 months. He was terminated from his job 4 weeks ago after he ceased attending work. Since his unemployment, he has been focused on creating a device to prevent people from controlling his mind.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No significant medical or psychiatric history reported.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Previously employed. No history of substance abuse reported. Married.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: No significant findings. Denies any drug use, recent travel, or physical health issues.

title: Sudden-onset abdominal pain — Testicular torsion
chief_complaint: Sudden-onset abdominal pain

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and diagnose the patient presenting with sudden-onset lower abdominal pain, with consideration of the patient's recent history and physical examination findings.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient reports the sudden onset of abdominal pain while playing football two hours ago. He has a past medical history significant only for asthma. Additionally, his social history is notable for unprotected sex with four partners in the past month.

Patient_Actor.Social_History: Unprotected sex with multiple partners. No use of tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs reported.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies fever, vomiting, diarrhea, dysuria, hematuria, or back pain.

Palpation.Findings: Right testicle is elevated with a horizontal lie, pain on elevation (negative Prehn's sign). Cremastric reflex is absent on the right side.

Scrotal_Ultrasound.Findings: Decreased blood flow to the right testicle, suggestive of testicular torsion.

title: Low-grade fever and itchy rash — Serum sickness-like reaction
chief_complaint: Low-grade fever and itchy rash

The rash initially started in the antecubital and popliteal fossae before spreading to the trunk and distal extremities. One week ago, she was diagnosed with acute sinusitis and started on amoxicillin. She has no history of adverse drug reactions, and her immunizations are up to date.

Secondary_Symptoms: Rash in the antecubital and popliteal fossae
Rash spread to trunk and distal extremities

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Diagnosed with acute sinusitis one week ago, no known history of adverse drug reactions, immunizations up to date.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: No significant social history provided.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: No additional symptoms mentioned.

Findings: Multiple erythematous, annular plaques of variable sizes over the entire body
One lesion in the right popliteal fossa has an area of central clearing

Joint_Examination.Findings: Generalized joint pain, no swelling or redness observed

title: Pain localized to the left knee — Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD)

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No significant past medical or surgical history.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: The patient is in the second grade, lives with parents and one younger sibling. No exposure to tobacco or known toxins.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies recent illness, rash, weight loss, change in appetite or urinary symptoms.

Musculoskeletal_Examination.Inspection: No visible deformity, swelling, or bruising of the knee or hip
Musculoskeletal_Examination.Palpation: Tenderness on palpation of the left hip, not knee
Musculoskeletal_Examination.Range_of_Motion: Full range of motion in the knee; pain elicited with passive motion of the hip
Musculoskeletal_Examination.Special_Tests: Negative for anterior drawer test and McMurray's, suggesting no knee joint instability or meniscal tear

X-ray_Left_Hip.Findings: Flattening and fragmentation of the left femoral head consistent with Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease

title: Aggressive cough with thick, yellow-green sputum — Bronchiectasis
chief_complaint: Aggressive cough with thick, yellow-green sputum

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No other significant past medical history aside from the recurrent bronchitis.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Non-smoker, no history of alcohol or drug abuse.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies any fever, weight loss, night sweats, or shortness of breath.

Respiratory_Examination.Inspection: No cyanosis or use of accessory muscles for breathing.
Respiratory_Examination.Auscultation: Crackles and wheezing over the right middle lobe.

Chest_X-ray.Findings: Irregular opacities in the right middle lobe and diffuse airway thickening.

Sputum_Culture.Findings: Heavy growth of non-specific bacteria, no TB or fungal growth.

title: Generalized erythematous maculopapular rash and pustules — Erythema Toxicum
chief_complaint: Generalized erythematous maculopapular rash and pustules

title: Weakness and fatigue — Myasthenia gravis
chief_complaint: Weakness and fatigue

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose the patient presenting with weakness and fatigue.

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No significant past medical history provided.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Enjoys outdoor activities such as hiking and camping. No mention of smoking, alcohol, or drug use.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies fever, weight loss, headache, or any respiratory, gastrointestinal, or urinary symptoms.

Acetylcholine_Receptor_Antibody.Interpretation: Indicates the presence of autoantibodies to acetylcholine receptors, which is associated with myasthenia gravis.

Electromyography_and_Nerve_Conduction_St.Finding: Decreased response with repetitive nerve stimulation, suggestive of a neuromuscular junction disorder.

title: Brown, greasy-looking lesions on the forehead — Seborrheic keratosis
chief_complaint: Brown, greasy-looking lesions on the forehead

Skin_Examination.Dermatoscopy: A network of cerebriform patterns without evidence of melanocytic activity.

Biopsy_Report.Histopathology: Hyperkeratosis with horn cysts, consistent with seborrheic keratosis.

title: Shortness of breath — Silicosis
chief_complaint: Shortness of breath

chief_complaint: Sudden, painless loss of vision in the right eye

title: Episode of loss of consciousness — Vasovagal syncope

She regained consciousness within 30 seconds, alert and fully oriented immediately after the episode. No known history of serious illness. She works as an event manager and reports experiencing higher levels of stress due to a recent concert tour.

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No significant history of medical illness.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Works as an event manager, has been experiencing significant stress due to work demands. No reported use of tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs.

title: Severe vulvar itching — Lichen Sclerosus
chief_complaint: Severe vulvar itching

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Type 2 diabetes mellitus (diet-controlled), hypertension (treated with hydrochlorothiazide), menopause at 52 years of age.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Married, sexually active with her husband until recently due to severe pain. Non-smoker, drinks alcohol socially.

Gynecologic_Examination.Bimanual_Examination: Nontender uterus and adnexa. No masses palpated.

Pap_Smear.Findings: Negative for intraepithelial lesion or malignancy

Biopsy_of_Vulvar_Lesions.Histopathology: Hyperkeratosis with a thinning of the epidermis and loss of rete ridges, sclerotic changes in the dermis.

Blood_Glucose.Fasting_Glucose_Level: 6.5 mmol/L (117 mg/dL) - Indicative of controlled diabetes.

title: Abdominal cramps — Bacillus cereus infection
chief_complaint: Abdominal cramps

title: Worsening shortness of breath — Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
chief_complaint: Worsening shortness of breath

title: Irritability — Tetralogy of Fallot

title: Hypopigmented skin lesions — Vitiligo
chief_complaint: Hypopigmented skin lesions

Patient_Actor.History: The patient reports noticing several areas of skin that have become lighter over the past several months. These patches have slowly increased in size. He also mentions that his father has a similar condition. The patient denies any recent illnesses, fever, or previous similar episodes. He is concerned about the cosmetic appearance of these lesions.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No significant past medical history. Not on any medications.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Full-time college student. Non-smoker. Occasional alcohol use.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies recent illnesses, fever, weight loss, or other systemic symptoms.

Skin_Examination.Inspection: Multiple well-demarcated, hypopigmented macules and patches over the face, hands, and arms. No erythema or scale. Hair and nails are normal.
Skin_Examination.Palpation: Skin texture is normal within and around the lesions. No warmth or induration.

Skin_Biopsy.Microscopic_Examination: Absence of melanocytes in the epidermis. Normal keratinocyte structure. No evidence of fungal elements.

chief_complaint: Progressive pain and blurry vision in the right eye

Professionally, he is engaged as a kindergarten teacher.

Secondary_Symptoms: No symptoms in the left eye

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Bronchial Asthma treated with inhaled salbutamol
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Kindergarten teacher, no reported smoking or significant alcohol use
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies fever, nausea, or any other systemic symptoms

Ophthalmic_Examination.Palpation: No abnormalities noted on palpation around the orbit or eye

Skin_Biopsy.Findings: Histopathological examination shows compact hyperkeratosis and reduced or absent granular layer, consistent with the clinical diagnosis.

title: Disturbing flashbacks and intense fear of loud noises — Posttraumatic stress disorder
chief_complaint: Disturbing flashbacks and intense fear of loud noises
